questions.question: Memory that temporarily stores data and loses it when power is off.
questions.explanation: RAM is volatile memory used for temporary data storage during computer operation.

questions.question: Memory that permanently stores data and keeps it when power is off.
questions.explanation: ROM contains permanent instructions that remain even without power.

questions.question: Storage device using magnetic platters and a read/write head.
questions.explanation: HDDs use spinning magnetic disks to store large amounts of data.

questions.question: Storage device using flash memory with no moving parts.
questions.explanation: SSDs use electronic flash memory for faster and more reliable storage.

questions.question: Small, fast memory located between CPU and RAM.
questions.explanation: Cache stores frequently accessed data for quick retrieval by the CPU.

questions.question: Storage unit equal to 1024 megabytes.
questions.explanation: A gigabyte is a common measure of storage capacity.

questions.question: Storage unit equal to 1024 gigabytes.
questions.explanation: A terabyte represents one trillion bytes of storage.

questions.question: Hard disk space used as additional RAM when needed.
questions.explanation: Virtual memory extends RAM capacity by using hard drive space temporarily.

questions.question: Portable storage device that plugs into a USB port.
questions.explanation: Flash drives are portable, removable storage devices using flash memory.

questions.question: The smallest unit of computer memory.
questions.explanation: A bit is a binary digit, either 0 or 1, the fundamental unit of computer data.
